name: Predicting Genetic Outcomes
what: This subtopic covers the tools and techniques used to predict inheritance patterns, including Punnett squares for calculating offspring ratios and pedigree charts for tracing traits through family generations.
why: Being able to predict genetic outcomes has practical applications in agriculture, medicine, and family planning. These tools help determine the probability of offspring inheriting specific traits or genetic conditions.

items.title: I can draw and label a Punnett square
items.what: A Punnett square is a grid used to predict the possible offspring from a genetic cross. One parent's alleles are written across the top, the other parent's alleles down the side. Each box shows a possible allele combination in offspring.
items.why: Punnett squares provide a systematic way to visualise all possible genetic outcomes of a cross. They help predict the probability of offspring inheriting particular genotypes and phenotypes.
items.example: To cross two heterozygous brown-eyed parents (Bb Ã— Bb): Write B and b across the top and down the side. Fill in each box by combining the row and column alleles. Results: BB, Bb, Bb, bb.

items.title: I can interpret the phenotypic and genotypic ratio of offspring
items.what: Genotypic ratio describes the proportion of each genotype in offspring (e.g., 1 BB : 2 Bb : 1 bb). Phenotypic ratio describes the proportion of each observable trait (e.g., 3 brown : 1 blue). These ratios represent probabilities, not guaranteed outcomes.
items.why: Understanding ratios helps predict the likelihood of offspring having particular traits. In genetic counselling, these ratios help families understand the chances of children inheriting genetic conditions.
items.example: When two heterozygous parents (Bb Ã— Bb) have children, the genotypic ratio is 1:2:1 (1 BB : 2 Bb : 1 bb). The phenotypic ratio is 3:1 (3 brown-eyed : 1 blue-eyed) because BB and Bb both produce brown eyes.

items.title: I can explain and draw a pedigree using pedigree rules
items.what: A pedigree chart shows inheritance patterns across multiple generations of a family. Squares represent males, circles represent females. Filled shapes indicate affected individuals, empty shapes indicate unaffected. Horizontal lines connect couples, vertical lines connect to offspring.
items.why: Pedigree charts help identify inheritance patterns by showing how traits pass through families. They can reveal whether a trait is dominant, recessive, or sex-linked, and help identify carriers of genetic conditions.
items.example: A pedigree for colour vision deficiency might show that affected individuals (filled shapes) are mostly males, with unaffected carrier females linking generations. This pattern suggests X-linked recessive inheritance.

items.title: I can determine the genotype of an individual from a pedigree
items.what: By analysing a pedigree, you can often deduce an individual's genotype. Affected individuals showing a recessive trait must be homozygous recessive. Unaffected parents of affected children must be carriers (heterozygous).
items.why: Determining genotypes from pedigrees helps predict the risk of genetic conditions in future generations. This information is valuable for genetic counselling and understanding family health history.
items.example: If two unaffected parents have a child with cystic fibrosis (recessive condition), both parents must be carriers (Cc). The affected child must be homozygous recessive (cc). Each future child has a 25% chance of being affected.
